title: 'Guamoji' put local spin on mobile chats 41 minutes ago
content:
Emoji made in Guam. (Photo: Courtesy Toni Brooks) 

Earlier this month, Toni Brooks and Elizabeth San Nicolas launched Guamoji, Guam-inspired images for chatting through text messaging and social media. 

Guamoji, similar to emoji or Facebook stickers, each convey a unique idea, give quick shortcuts for communication. 

“Well, we chat a lot; a lot,” said Brooks, a freelance graphic designer. “We’re always saying local phrases to each other.” 

“Like, we wish there was a sticker for that,” said San Nicolas. “So we just made our own.” 

The first “package” includes 20 freely available Guamoji, which Brooks said captures many of Guam’s “well-known icons.” 

Among them are a fiesta plate — complete with red rice and fina’denne’, as well as a flying proa, latte and donne peppers. 

“It started as a really fun project for our friends just to be hilarious and chat as we always are,” said Brooks, “and then we had this idea — ‘Wait, hold on. Do you think people will buy this? Let’s try it!’” 

Emoji made in Guam.   (Photo: Courtesy Toni Brooks) 

Both women have backgrounds in web development and design, and the Guamoji project allows them to bridge their tech backgrounds and their Chamorro roots. 

“I’m sure you used text smilies way back in the day,” said Brooks. “And it just kinda evolves to the point where we need our own representation in that digital world.” 

“And when you’re talking on this thing,” added San Nicolas, holding up a cell phone. “Time is of the essence, and less buttons to press is a good thing.” 

And creating their own way of communicating, Brooks said, “makes it more personal.” 

Currently, users share Guamoji by copying them or saving them from an online library and pasting them into mobile chats. 

Brooks and San Nicolas said an actual keyboard application is in the works, which would allow for a much more streamlined interface. 

However, that will require tackling all the different requirements needed across the various platforms people would be sending Guamoji on. 

“That’s the biggest barrier is getting it implemented across different platforms,” Brooks said, noting that the keyboard will also allow them to collect much more content-focused feedback. 

Preliminary feedback, she said though, has been mostly positive. 

“It’s funny and it’s cute and it’s, I dunno, really happy,” she added. 

Brooks said they’ve already started working with a Guam-native programmer in the states, who is helping develop the keyboard app. 

“That’s in demo phase now, so we’re still working out the kinks,” Brooks said. 

She said once that’s approved through the Apple App Store, they’ll be ready for launch. 

Their goal for that, she said, is Christmas. 

“And then after that, after we get the iPhone app out, we’ll start Android development,” she said. 

In addition to the app, Brooks and San Nicolas are also working on various themed “packages” of Guamoji. 

Following Typhoon Soudelor, the duo designed and launched a pack of 20 typhoon-oriented Guamoji. 

The pack sells for 99 cents on the Guamoji website with a portion of the proceeds going toward relief efforts in Saipan via the Ayuda Foundation. 

The site uses a third-party app called “Cointent” to process transactions, similar to PayPal. 

Brooks said the devastation in Saipan inspired the women to “do something.” 

“I guess this is our way of dealing,” she said, “through cute images.” 

San Nicolas noted that Guam is no stranger to the effects of typhoons. 

“So when the typhoon hit Saipan,” she said, “the next pack, we didn’t decide yet, so we decided ‘OK, we’ll do a typhoon one and help raise some money.” 

The typhoon pack includes a variety of Guamoji that focus particularly on storm preparation and includes images of batteries, generators and, Brooks’ favorite, typhoon shutters. 

“Because it’s animated,” she said. 

The pair also has some theme packs lined up for release in the future. 

Among them will be animal-themed package, featuring English and Chamorro names of Guam’s creatures. 

“And I’m really looking forward to creating those, because they’re going to be so adorable,” Brooks said. 

A local myths and legends package is slated for release next month, she added. 

Brooks and San Nicolas also said that for anybody looking to create their own art, there’s a slew of resources available in Guam.
